I'm not aware of any such change.  I suppose that as the samurai class got squeezed financially, mounts may have been simplified.  If anything the fancier koshirae in the Edo period were more likely to be fully outfitted with kozuka and kogai.

Some of the filled ana that we see were added by collectors after the tsuba were no longer worn.  I don't know how many that accounts for.

Jim



  Has anyone ever heard any theories on why you see so many tsuba with 
  ume in their hitsuana?  Was there possibly a change in style or 
  utilization into Edo which eliminated the need for the utensils?  
  Thanks!
